questions.text: Pencil is acceptable for Section B if your writing is neat and legible.
questions.explanation: Use blue or black ink pen for Section B. Papers are scanned, and pencil often comes out too faint for assessors to read reliably.
questions.studyTip: Bring a reliable pen. Pencil doesn't scan well.

questions.text: Assessors mark scanned images of your paper, so ink pen is essential for Section B.
questions.explanation: Papers are scanned, not marked directly. Ink shows up clearly; pencil can be unreadable.
questions.studyTip: Blue or black ink works best for scanning.

questions.text: Writing outside the marked boundaries is fine if your answer is complete.
questions.explanation: Assessors see scanned images within the marked boundaries. Anything outside may be cut off and never seen.
questions.studyTip: Stay inside the lines—assessors can't see what's cut off.

questions.text: If you continue a response in extra space, you must clearly number it to match the question.
questions.explanation: When using extra space, clearly indicate which question you're continuing. This helps assessors find and credit your full response.
questions.studyTip: Label continued answers clearly: 'Q3 continued'.

questions.text: If asked to 'identify one role', providing two roles gives you a better chance of getting the mark.
questions.explanation: Assessors can only mark the number of responses asked for. If asked for one, they read only your first response—extra answers are ignored.
questions.studyTip: 'Identify one' means give one. Extra answers won't be read.

questions.text: Providing more responses than asked for can result in your additional answers being ignored.
questions.explanation: Assessors mark only the number requested. If you give three when asked for two, the third is disregarded entirely.
questions.studyTip: Match your response count to the question exactly.

questions.text: A definition of the key term is usually sufficient for scenario-based questions.
questions.explanation: Scenario questions require you to apply psychological knowledge to the specific context given. Definitions alone rarely earn full marks.
questions.studyTip: Don't just define—connect your answer to the scenario.

questions.text: Questions asking you to apply knowledge to a scenario require explicit references to details in that scenario.
questions.explanation: Make clear how your answer relates to the specific people, situations, or data in the scenario. Generic explanations lose marks.
questions.studyTip: Name names, quote data, reference specific details.

questions.text: 'Explain' and 'describe' require the same level of detail in your response.
questions.explanation: 'Describe' means state what something is. 'Explain' means show how or why something works. Explanation requires more depth and reasoning.
questions.studyTip: Describe = what. Explain = how/why.

questions.text: Understanding command terms like 'evaluate', 'explain', and 'with reference to' helps you give assessors what they're looking for.
questions.explanation: Each command term signals a specific type of response. 'Evaluate' needs pros and cons. 'With reference to' requires using provided data.
questions.studyTip: Learn the VCAA glossary of command terms.

questions.text: If you're running out of time on the extended response, it's better to leave it blank than write an incomplete answer.
questions.explanation: Any attempt can earn marks. Students who wrote partial extended responses still scored 6–7 out of 10 when other criteria were met well.
questions.studyTip: Something is better than nothing—always attempt the extended response.

questions.text: You should provide a response to every multiple-choice question, even if guessing.
questions.explanation: Marks are not deducted for incorrect answers. A guess has a 25% chance of being right; a blank has 0%.
questions.studyTip: Never leave MCQs blank—no penalty for wrong answers.

questions.text: Labelling 'regular' and 'irregular' under bar columns is sufficient without an axis label.
questions.explanation: You need both: individual bar labels AND an axis label (e.g., 'traveller type'). Missing axis labels cost marks.
questions.studyTip: Every axis needs a label, plus label each bar.

questions.text: The y-axis should show the dependent variable with an appropriate scale including units if applicable.
questions.explanation: The dependent variable goes on the y-axis. Include a clear label, units where relevant, and a scale starting from an appropriate value.
questions.studyTip: DV on y-axis. Label it. Scale it. Get the mark.

questions.text: In a bar chart, the columns should touch each other since they represent related categories.
questions.explanation: Bar chart columns must NOT touch. Touching columns indicate a histogram (continuous data). Categorical data needs gaps between bars.
questions.studyTip: Bar chart = gaps between bars. Histogram = no gaps.

questions.text: Bar charts are appropriate for categorical data like 'regular' vs 'irregular' travellers.
questions.explanation: Categorical (discrete) data uses bar charts with separated columns. Line graphs or histograms are for continuous data.
questions.studyTip: Categories = bar chart with gaps.

questions.text: Stating that 'the IV has an impact on the DV' is sufficient for a conclusion.
questions.explanation: You must specify the direction of impact. Did it increase or decrease? 'Higher' or 'lower'? Vague statements like 'had an impact' lose marks.
questions.studyTip: Always state direction: increased, decreased, higher, lower.

questions.text: Conclusions should specify whether the relationship between variables is positive, negative, or the exact direction of difference.
questions.explanation: Don't just say variables are 'related'. State how: 'Group A scored higher than Group B' or 'as X increased, Y decreased'.
questions.studyTip: Direction is mandatory: 'increased by', 'was higher than'.

questions.text: When asked to draw conclusions 'referring to results', you can summarise without quoting specific numbers.
questions.explanation: When prompted to 'refer to results', you must include specific data values. General statements without numbers don't demonstrate you've used the data.
questions.studyTip: 'Referring to results' = quote actual numbers.

questions.text: Comparing results across groups requires referencing specific scores from the data provided.
questions.explanation: Don't just say one group 'did better'. State: 'Group A scored 3.2 compared to Group B's 1.8'. Specific comparisons show understanding.
questions.studyTip: Quote both values when comparing groups.

questions.text: A line graph is appropriate for displaying mean scores of different experimental conditions.
questions.explanation: Different conditions are categorical, not continuous—use a bar chart. Line graphs imply continuity between points, which is misleading for discrete categories.
questions.studyTip: Conditions/groups = bar chart. Continuous change = line graph.

questions.text: When plotting percentage differences between age groups, a bar chart with non-touching bars is appropriate.
questions.explanation: Age groups are categories. Each bar represents a distinct category, so bars should not touch.
questions.studyTip: Discrete categories always get separated bars.

questions.text: If comparing two groups measured once each, you can conclude which group was more 'affected' by the condition.
questions.explanation: In between-subjects designs without pre-test data, you can only compare outcomes, not impact. You don't know what the groups were like before.
questions.studyTip: No pre-test = no claim about 'impact' or 'change'.

questions.text: Between-subjects designs allow you to compare outcomes between groups, but not changes within groups.
questions.explanation: Without baseline measurements, you can say Group A scored higher than Group B. You cannot say the condition 'changed' Group A more.
questions.studyTip: Compare outcomes, not impacts, without pre-test data.

questions.text: The variable you measure to see the effect of your manipulation is the independent variable.
questions.explanation: That's the dependent variable (DV). The independent variable (IV) is what you manipulate or change. IV → DV: cause → effect.
questions.studyTip: IV = what you change. DV = what you measure.

questions.text: The independent variable is the factor manipulated or controlled by the researcher.
questions.explanation: The IV is deliberately varied to see its effect on the DV. In an experiment, the researcher controls the IV conditions.
questions.studyTip: The researcher controls the IV; the IV affects the DV.

questions.text: Extraneous variables and confounding variables are the same thing.
questions.explanation: Extraneous variables are controlled for or eliminated. Confounding variables actually affect results and weren't controlled, potentially invalidating conclusions.
questions.studyTip: Extraneous = controlled. Confounding = affected results.

questions.text: Excluding problematic data (like responses completed too quickly) controls for extraneous variables.
questions.explanation: Removing responses that indicate participants didn't engage properly (e.g., completing in under 1 minute) prevents this extraneous factor from affecting results.
questions.studyTip: Eliminated data = controlled extraneous variable, not confounding.

questions.text: Data from a questionnaire using a rating scale is qualitative data.
questions.explanation: Rating scale scores (e.g., 1–4) are quantitative—they're numbers you can calculate with. Qualitative data is descriptive, like open-ended responses.
questions.studyTip: Numbers = quantitative. Words/descriptions = qualitative.

questions.text: Questionnaire data can be classified as quantitative, primary, or subjective depending on context.
questions.explanation: Rating scales are quantitative. If researchers collect it themselves, it's primary. Self-reported feelings are subjective. Know what's being asked.
questions.studyTip: One source can be multiple data types—identify what's relevant.

questions.text: Saying data would 'impact the accuracy' is sufficient when explaining effects on validity.
questions.explanation: You must specify direction. Would it increase or decrease accuracy/validity? Saying something 'impacts' results doesn't show you understand how.
questions.studyTip: 'Decreases validity' or 'reduces accuracy'—state direction.

questions.text: Including unreliable data (like rushed responses) would decrease the internal validity of an experiment.
questions.explanation: Rushed responses may be inaccurate, introducing error. This reduces your ability to draw accurate cause-effect conclusions (internal validity).
questions.studyTip: Bad data → less valid conclusions.

questions.text: Random sampling means each participant in your sample has an equal chance of being selected for a condition.
questions.explanation: That's random allocation. Random sampling means each member of the population has an equal chance of being selected for the sample itself.
questions.studyTip: Random sampling = from population. Random allocation = to conditions.

questions.text: In random sampling, every member of the target population has an equal chance of selection.
questions.explanation: This creates a representative sample. Combined with sufficient sample size, it allows generalisation to the broader population.
questions.studyTip: Population → random sampling → representative sample.

questions.text: Reproducibility means getting similar results when repeating the experiment under identical conditions.
questions.explanation: That's repeatability (same conditions). Reproducibility means getting similar results under changed conditions—different researcher, equipment, or sample.
questions.studyTip: Same conditions = repeatability. Changed conditions = reproducibility.

questions.text: To test reproducibility, you must change at least one condition of the experiment before comparing results.
questions.explanation: Reproducibility checks if findings hold when conditions vary—new researcher, different equipment, different sample. Robustness across changes.
questions.studyTip: Reproduce = repeat with something different.

questions.text: Systematic errors affect measurements randomly, making some too high and others too low.
questions.explanation: Systematic errors consistently skew measurements in one direction. Random errors vary unpredictably. The H-index in spinal reflex studies eliminates systematic error from height differences.
questions.studyTip: Systematic = consistent bias. Random = unpredictable variation.

questions.text: Accounting for participant height in reflexology measurements eliminates a systematic error.
questions.explanation: Height consistently affects reflex measurements. The H-index compensates for this, removing the systematic bias and improving accuracy.
questions.studyTip: Consistent bias = systematic error. Remove it.

questions.text: In classical conditioning, the neutral stimulus can be presented after the unconditioned stimulus.
questions.explanation: The NS must be presented before or simultaneously with the UCS. Presenting NS after UCS doesn't create the association needed for conditioning.
questions.studyTip: NS comes before (or with) UCS—never after.

questions.text: Successful classical conditioning requires the neutral stimulus to be repeatedly paired with the unconditioned stimulus.
questions.explanation: Repetition strengthens the association. Single pairings rarely produce lasting conditioning. Repeated NS + UCS pairings lead to NS becoming CS.
questions.studyTip: Repetition + correct timing = successful conditioning.

questions.text: In operant conditioning, the consequence always comes before the behaviour.
questions.explanation: The sequence is Antecedent → Behaviour → Consequence. Consequences follow behaviour and influence whether it's repeated.
questions.studyTip: A-B-C: Antecedent, Behaviour, Consequence—always in order.

questions.text: Positive reinforcement increases behaviour by adding a desirable stimulus after the behaviour.
questions.explanation: The cow gets a sugar treat after urinating in the pen. This pleasant consequence increases the likelihood of repeating the behaviour.
questions.studyTip: Positive = adding. Reinforcement = increases behaviour.

questions.text: Long-term potentiation occurs after a single stimulation of a neural pathway.
questions.explanation: LTP requires repeated co-activation of neurons. Single stimulations don't produce lasting synaptic strengthening. Practice makes permanent.
questions.studyTip: LTP needs repeated stimulation—not just once.

questions.text: Long-term potentiation involves the strengthening of synaptic connections due to repeated stimulation.
questions.explanation: When neurons repeatedly fire together, their connection strengthens. This is the neural basis of memory formation and learning.
questions.studyTip: Neurons that fire together, wire together (through LTP).

questions.text: The hippocampus is involved in storing implicit memories like motor skills.
questions.explanation: The hippocampus handles explicit (declarative) memory—facts and events. Implicit memories involve the basal ganglia and cerebellum.
questions.studyTip: Hippocampus = explicit. Basal ganglia/cerebellum = implicit.

questions.text: The basal ganglia and cerebellum interact with the neocortex to encode and store procedural memories.
questions.explanation: Motor skills involve the basal ganglia (habit formation) and cerebellum (fine motor movements), with storage in the neocortex.
questions.studyTip: Procedural memory = basal ganglia + cerebellum + neocortex.

questions.text: The vagus nerve only transmits messages from the brain to the gut.
questions.explanation: The vagus nerve is bidirectional. About 80–90% of fibres carry sensory information from gut to brain; 10–20% carry motor signals from brain to gut.
questions.studyTip: Vagus = bidirectional. Mostly gut → brain (80–90%).

questions.text: The vagus nerve enables bidirectional communication between the central nervous system and the enteric nervous system.
questions.explanation: It connects the brain and gut, allowing the gut-brain axis to function. Neural messages travel both directions via the vagus nerve.
questions.studyTip: Vagus nerve = the gut-brain axis highway.

questions.text: Lazarus and Folkman's model can fully explain physiological responses like increased heart rate.
questions.explanation: Lazarus and Folkman's Transactional Model focuses on psychological appraisal. It has limited explanatory power for purely physiological responses.
questions.studyTip: Transactional model = psychological. GAS = biological.

questions.text: Each stress model has different explanatory power depending on whether you're examining biological or psychological aspects.
questions.explanation: Selye's GAS explains biological stress responses. Lazarus and Folkman explain psychological appraisal. Choose the model that fits what you're analysing.
questions.studyTip: Match the model to the aspect of stress you're explaining.

questions.text: Melatonin is released directly from the suprachiasmatic nucleus.
questions.explanation: The SCN detects light and sends signals to the pineal gland, which releases melatonin. The SCN regulates the timing, not the release itself.
questions.studyTip: SCN → signals → pineal gland → melatonin.

questions.text: Blue light detected by the SCN leads to inhibition of melatonin release from the pineal gland.
questions.explanation: Light signals the SCN that it's daytime. The SCN sends inhibitory signals to the pineal gland, delaying melatonin and promoting wakefulness.
questions.studyTip: Light → SCN → inhibits pineal → delays melatonin → stay awake.

questions.text: Possible imagined futures only use episodic memories, not semantic memories.
questions.explanation: Both episodic and semantic autobiographical memories contribute to imagining the future. You combine personal experiences with general knowledge.
questions.studyTip: Imagined futures = episodic + semantic working together.

questions.text: Episodic and semantic memories interact to actively construct simulations of possible future events.
questions.explanation: You use episodic memories of past experiences combined with semantic knowledge about how things work to imagine plausible future scenarios.
questions.studyTip: Past experiences + general knowledge = imagined futures.

questions.text: Sensory neurons 'travel' from the receptors to the spinal cord.
questions.explanation: Neurons don't travel—they're stationary cells. Neural information (electrochemical signals) travels along neurons. Be precise with language.
questions.studyTip: Neurons don't move. Information travels along neurons.

questions.text: Neural information travels along sensory pathways to the spinal cord, not the neurons themselves.
questions.explanation: The electrical impulse (action potential) moves along the fixed neuron. Saying neurons 'travel' suggests misunderstanding of basic neuroscience.
questions.studyTip: Information travels; neurons stay put.

questions.text: Mindfulness meditation is essentially the same as breathing retraining.
questions.explanation: Mindfulness has two key components: focused attention (often on breathing) AND acceptance/non-judgement of thoughts. Breathing retraining focuses only on changing breathing patterns.
questions.studyTip: Mindfulness = attention + acceptance. Both components required.

questions.text: Mindfulness meditation requires both focused attention and non-judgemental acceptance of thoughts and feelings.
questions.explanation: It's not just about breathing. You must acknowledge thoughts without judging them—letting them pass rather than fighting them.
questions.studyTip: Attention on present + accept without judgement = mindfulness.

questions.text: In the exhaustion stage of GAS, adrenaline is depleted, causing burnout.
questions.explanation: In exhaustion, it's cortisol that becomes depleted—the body can no longer maintain elevated cortisol levels. Adrenaline is relevant to the alarm stage.
questions.studyTip: Exhaustion stage = cortisol depletion, not adrenaline.

questions.text: The exhaustion stage of General Adaptation Syndrome involves depletion of cortisol resources.
questions.explanation: Prolonged stress exhausts the body's ability to maintain elevated cortisol. This depletion leads to vulnerability to illness and burnout.
questions.studyTip: Chronic stress depletes cortisol → exhaustion.

questions.text: Qualitative data is inherently inferior to quantitative data.
questions.explanation: Each data type has different strengths. Qualitative provides rich, detailed insight into experiences. Quantitative allows statistical analysis. Neither is universally better.
questions.studyTip: Qualitative = rich detail. Quantitative = statistics. Different purposes.

questions.text: Subjective data from questionnaires can provide insight into experiences that cannot be directly observed.
questions.explanation: Inner experiences like mental wellbeing, stress perception, or emotions can only be accessed through self-report. This is a strength of subjective data.
questions.studyTip: Subjective data accesses internal experiences.

questions.text: Voluntary participation and withdrawal rights refer to the same ethical concept.
questions.explanation: Voluntary participation means freely choosing to join the study. Withdrawal rights mean being able to leave at any time without penalty. These are distinct guidelines.
questions.studyTip: Voluntary = choosing to join. Withdrawal = choosing to leave.

questions.text: Participants must both voluntarily agree to participate AND retain the right to withdraw at any time.
questions.explanation: These are two separate ethical protections. Consent to participate doesn't waive the right to withdraw. Both must be upheld.
questions.studyTip: Two separate rights: join freely, leave freely.

questions.text: Terms like 'appraise', 'perceive', and 'resources to cope' are appropriate when describing Selye's GAS model.
questions.explanation: Those terms belong to Lazarus and Folkman's Transactional Model. Selye's GAS uses biological terms: alarm, resistance, exhaustion, cortisol, physiological responses.
questions.studyTip: Match your terminology to the correct model.

questions.text: Selye's General Adaptation Syndrome focuses on biological responses to stress, not cognitive appraisal.
questions.explanation: GAS describes physical stress responses through stages. Appraisal is a cognitive concept from Lazarus and Folkman's model. Keep models distinct.
questions.studyTip: GAS = biological stages. Transactional = cognitive appraisal.

questions.text: The retention stage of observational learning involves maintaining a visual image in short-term memory.
questions.explanation: Retention involves forming a mental representation stored in long-term memory. Short-term storage would mean the skill couldn't be performed days later.
questions.studyTip: Retention = mental representation in LTM, not just visual image in STM.

questions.text: Retention in observational learning refers to storing a mental representation of the observed behaviour in long-term memory.
questions.explanation: To reproduce behaviour later (like in the next lesson), the mental representation must be encoded into long-term memory during retention.
questions.studyTip: Observed → retained in LTM → reproduced later.

questions.text: Neuromodulators are unique because they can be both inhibitory and excitatory.
questions.explanation: Neurotransmitters can also be inhibitory or excitatory. Neuromodulators are distinguished by slow release, long-lasting effects, and far-reaching impact over widespread brain regions.
questions.studyTip: Neuromodulator features: slow, long-lasting, widespread.

questions.text: Neuromodulators have far-reaching effects across widespread brain regions and produce long-lasting changes.
questions.explanation: Unlike neurotransmitters acting at specific synapses, neuromodulators diffuse widely and modulate activity across multiple neurons over extended periods.
questions.studyTip: Neuromodulators = broad, slow, lasting effects.

questions.text: For the extended response, addressing just two of three components really well is better than addressing all three briefly.
questions.explanation: Higher marks require addressing each component. Students who covered all criteria scored higher, even if the quality wasn't perfect throughout.
questions.studyTip: Address all parts of extended questions—coverage matters.

questions.text: Using subheadings can help structure your extended response and ensure you address all components.
questions.explanation: Subheadings help you organise your thinking and make it easier for assessors to see you've covered all required aspects.
questions.studyTip: Subheadings = structure for you, clarity for assessors.

questions.text: Providing the textbook definition of an ethical concept is usually sufficient for application questions.
questions.explanation: You must apply the concept to the specific scenario. For integrity, don't just define it—explain how it applies to administering questionnaires AND reporting results.
questions.studyTip: Definition + specific application = full marks.

questions.text: Ethical guidelines like integrity need to be applied to multiple aspects of a study when the question asks for this.
questions.explanation: Questions may ask how one concept applies to two different aspects (e.g., collecting data AND reporting it). Address both explicitly.
questions.studyTip: Two aspects mentioned = two applications needed.

questions.text: Explaining what primary and secondary appraisal involve is sufficient when asked to evaluate the Transactional Model.
questions.explanation: 'Evaluate' requires you to judge effectiveness or limitations. Describing what the model does isn't evaluation—you must assess how well it explains the specific situation.
questions.studyTip: Evaluate = judge strengths/limitations, not just describe.

questions.text: To evaluate a model's explanatory power, you must assess how well it explains the specific phenomenon in question.
questions.explanation: Apply the model to the scenario and judge whether it accounts for what's observed. State clearly if it has high, low, or limited explanatory power for that case.
questions.studyTip: Good/limited explanatory power because... + reasoning.

questions.text: Stating that benzodiazepines reduce anxiety is sufficient when explaining how they treat phobias.
questions.explanation: You need the mechanism: benzodiazepines enhance GABA (the inhibitory neurotransmitter), which reduces neural activity in areas like the amygdala, decreasing the fear response.
questions.studyTip: State the mechanism: drug → neurotransmitter → brain effect → outcome.

questions.text: Explaining drug treatments requires connecting the drug's action on neurotransmitters to its effect on behaviour or symptoms.
questions.explanation: Chain of reasoning: Benzodiazepines → enhance GABA → inhibit amygdala activity → reduce anxiety/fear response. All links needed.
questions.studyTip: Complete causal chain: drug → brain → behaviour.

questions.text: When evaluating a treatment, stating it's 'effective' or 'not effective' is sufficient.
questions.explanation: You need specific strengths AND limitations. CBT targets the cause but takes time. Benzodiazepines work quickly but have side effects. Balance your evaluation.
questions.studyTip: Evaluation = at least one strength + one limitation.

questions.text: A balanced evaluation of a treatment includes specific strengths and specific limitations.
questions.explanation: Don't be one-sided. CBT addresses underlying thoughts but requires patient effort. Medication is faster but has side effects. Show nuance.
questions.studyTip: Pros AND cons—assessors want balanced analysis.

questions.text: Suggesting that researchers simply repeat the same experiment is a valid suggestion for future research.
questions.explanation: Future research means extending knowledge—changing the IV, DV, sample, or methodology. Repetition tests reliability, not new understanding.
questions.studyTip: Future research = change something to learn something new.

questions.text: Valid future research suggestions involve changing the independent variable, dependent variable, sample, or methodology.
questions.explanation: Propose meaningful extensions: different populations, different measures, different conditions. This shows understanding of how research progresses.
questions.studyTip: Suggest what to change AND why it would add value.

questions.text: Ways of knowing for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples can be explained using Western learning models.
questions.explanation: Aboriginal ways of knowing are unique, complex, and sophisticated systems distinct from Western approaches. They emphasise relationships, kinship, and connection to Country.
questions.studyTip: Aboriginal ways of knowing ≠ Western learning models.

questions.text: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander ways of knowing are holistic systems emphasising relationships, kinship, and Country.
questions.explanation: These systems integrate multiple elements: relationships determine who holds knowledge, kinship structures knowledge sharing, and learning is patterned on Country.
questions.studyTip: Holistic, relational, connected to Country and kinship.

questions.text: Simply stating that kinship supports wellbeing is sufficient when asked to describe how it supports SEWB.
questions.explanation: You must describe HOW: kinship provides belonging, maintains cultural ties, creates protective factors through connection to Elders and family history.
questions.studyTip: Don't restate the question—explain the mechanism.

questions.text: Describing how cultural determinants support SEWB requires explaining the mechanism of support, not just stating that they do.
questions.explanation: Explain specifically: cultural continuity through songlines maintains identity and belonging, which supports connection to culture as a SEWB domain.
questions.studyTip: HOW does it support wellbeing? Explain the link.
